_exec_summary.SummaryText:
at the Ventura Foods facility located at 2900 E. Jurupa Street in Ontario, California. The Ventura Foods PSM committee is planning to complete several items over the next year, as a continual effort to provide a safe work environment for their employees. These changes include the following items:

1. Continue to train all employees in the facility safety plan/programs.
2. Continue to have employee involvement in safety plan development.
3. Continue employee involvement through safety team participation.
4. Continue internal and external safety audits/inspections and implement changes as needed.

Response section of the PSM/RMP/CalARP document which is maintained at the facility. This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives:

¿ To save lives.
¿ To minimize and avoid injuries.
¿ To protect the environment.
¿ To minimize property damage.

The Ventura Foods facility maintains a PSM committee whose members include the designated Emergency Coordinator, as well as Emergency Coordinator alternates for the facility at a minimum. The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures, which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility. This Plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year. This Plan is reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the PSM, RMP, and CalARP regulations, as well as to incorporate facility changes.

The Ventura Foods facility will coordinate with the local emergency responders (fire department hazardous materials division) to assist with responding to ammonia incidents. The Ventura Foods facility plans to coordinate emergency response efforts with the fire department on a periodic and ongoing basis.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
An investigation into the facility's accident history conducted at the time of the Process Hazard Analysis Revalidation Study revealed that there have been no ammonia releases over the past five years (February 2014 to February 2019) that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity of 100 pounds or the state requirement mandating immediate reporting of any release or threatened release of a hazardous material. In addition, there have been no injuries resulting from an ammonia release, nor any releases that caused property damage onsite or offsite.
PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
The Process Hazards Analysis (February 13-14, 2019) including a Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) study and a Facility Inspection, provided mitigation measures to improve safety

cal states (high pressure liquid, low pressure liquid, low pressure vapor, high pressure vapor, then back to high pressure liquid) in order to provide refrigeration for the production of edible oil products and sauces. 

The majority of the system is located in the engine room including vessels and compressors. The condensers are mounted on the roof, and the evaporators, and heat exchangers are located in their respective cold areas.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The Ventura Foods ammonia refrigeration system has many safety features. Much of the safety of the system is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the system. For example, the facility operates in accordance with Cal/OSHA's Process Safety Management regulation. The facility conducts routine operations and maintenance, and any necessary minor repairs in house, but an outside contractor is hired for major repairs.

The facility including the ammonia system was designed and constructed in accordance with the Uniform Mechanical Code, which specifically outlines requirements for the safe operation of the ammonia refrigeration system. These safety features include ammonia sensors in the engine room as well as sensors near the evaporators, and automatic shut down systems. 

In addition, the majority of the ammonia is maintained inside the engine room and just outside of the engine room (condensers). All pressure vessels are equipped with pressure relief valves that are commonly piped to the water dilution tanks.

Ventura Foods has developed a preventive maintenance program to complete regularly scheduled inspections and tests of the ammonia refrigeration system as well as repairs as needed to process equipment.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLANNING

The Ventura Foods facility has an emergency action plan in effect. The Emergency Action Plan (Plan) has been developed by Ventura Foods and is included in the Emergency Planning and

This Executive Summary contains Ventura Foods administrative and operational programs to prevent ammonia-related accidents and reduce potential risks. The regulated substance of concern and focus of this document is anhydrous ammonia. The following topics are addressed in this Executive Summary:

¿ Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
¿ Stationary Source and Regulated Substance
¿ Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
¿ Emergency Response Plan
¿ Five Year Accident History
¿ Planned Changes to Improve Safety


ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES
Ventura Foods is strongly committed to employee, public, and environmental safety. This commitment is reflected in a comprehensive accidental release prevention program. This program addresses the design, installation, operation, maintenance, and employee training associated with the process solution equipment at the facility.

Ventura Foods management is not only committed to offering superior service, but also to maintaining a safety and environmental program to promote a safe environment for all its employees and the surrounding communities. Ventura Foods's safety and environmental policies as they relate to the ammonia refrigeration system are administered by the PSM Manager, who conducts inspections of the facility to ensure compliance.

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE
The system at 2900 E. Jurupa Street in Ontario, California was constructed in accordance with all applicable federal, state, and local regulations including the Uniform Fire and Mechanical Codes at the time of construction. The system has a maximum intended inventory of approximately 19,418 pounds of ammonia.
